utterances: And so, to me, it's just a matter of what your true conditions are.
And these people's true conditions are that this war is a correct thing, which (unintelligible).
Norman, Oklahoma.
Excellent.
Now, John, if I'm getting you correct, you're also implying that if most Americans agreed that the war was a good thing, then there might be more sympathy for Scooter Libby.
I am not implying it.
I'm saying it, yes.
Okay.
There we go.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Jeff, you know, what about the underlying issues?
The underlying issues that are behind this case really have to do with government accountability and how we got into this war.
Are those underlying issues going to be aired?
I think they're being aired now in this conversation, but I don't think they're going to be aired in the larger conversation.

I think we're becoming fixated on whether or not - and when I say, we, I mean in general, the mainstream - we're becoming fixated on whether or not Scooter Libby is going to serve his maximum sentence.
He's going to get a minimum sentence.
He's eventually going to have his name cleared.
And we're actually missing what this is about.

This is really about retribution and what happens when - in this case, an ambassador, Joseph Wilson - accuses the administration of doctoring up their intelligence prior to the war in Iraq, and what happens as a result, and that is that - guess what?
We're going to find a way to leak your wife's identity.
We're going to find a way to out a CIA operative and put that person in danger because this is what happens when you mess with the big boys.
And I think that's what happens.

Another point, to point out about this particular situation is that it's actually quite sad, because there's not - there won't be anymore indictments around this case, which means we'll never know who it was that really revealed the operative's identity.
There won't be any real punishment for the actual leak itself.
So Scooter Libby will be the fall guy, and to go - to add to what John said - in many circles will be seen as a hero because he protected the interests of national security.
And protected Vice President Cheney…
Indeed, and…
…and possibly the president.
Indeed.
And whether that's possible or not…
And the vice president said he was very disappointed with the verdict.
Is there going to be any kind of further investigation, you think - not necessarily, as you pointed out, there's not going to be anymore indictments, but there's still a civil suit, a civil trial.
Will there be more of an airing of the chain of command that may have led to these leaks?
Probably, but in a civil court, it's a little bit different.
It's not as glamorous as the criminal court.
And accountability - of course, they have more room to be able to explore things.
But I think that this is going to be a dead issue, pretty much…
A lot of this is going to come out in the memoirs, I suspect.
We're going to have to wait.
People are going to wait until (unintelligible) die down.
Or the movie.
The memoirs, the movie…
Indeed.
…and the presidential library.
We have all sorts of opportunities that might not take effect for another couple of years.
Anyway, in case you're just tuning in, you are listening to NPR's NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
We've got John McWhorter, Manhattan Institute senior fellow in public policy, E.R.
Shipp, professor in journalism at Hofstra University School of Communication, and Jeff Obafemi-Carr, host of the radio show Freestyle.
And, E.R., I got to bring this one to you.
Oh, Lord.
This - you know, it's all about the boys and the girls.
So all this month on NEWS & NOTES, we're talking to women in leadership positions.
In fact, tomorrow, we'll hear from Geraldine Ferraro.
But right now, I want to talk about why women may prefer men to take the lead in the workplace.
There was a study done by ELLE magazine and MSNBC.com, and it showed that three out of four women would rather have a male in charge.
The report said that women were more weary of dealing with the stereotypical catty boss lady.
What are we to make of our own kind, E.R.?
Well, it's not unlike how we look at our own kind racially.
We have been trained over the decades and over the centuries to look upon ourselves in negative ways.
So that survey showed that women saw that other women were moody, bitchy, gossipy, emotional, catty.
Those are all words that have been used over the centuries to downplay our roles in society.
Women have made that a part of their own identity to look at other women in that way, just as I think we're seeing with Barack Obama's campaign.
We're seeing some of that same kind of thing coming out with black people see themselves that they can't do, they can't beat.
It is sad, we're in the 21st century and we're still stuck with 1700, 1800 and 1900, you know, ideas about ourselves.
Jeff, I'm thinking of the movie ""The Devil Wears Prada"" and the stereotypic witchy boss.
Why do think women prefer male leadership, according to the study at least?

Well, I guess according to the study, I think that it speaks to the old notions of America, whether it's the ""Ozzie and Harriet"" ""Leave It To Beaver"" notion of this man going out and winning the bread and a woman staying home and baking cookies and putting them on the windowsill and…
Or wearing pearls.
Or wearing pearls, et cetera.
I think it buys into that notion.
And it buys into that notion not just for women, but for everybody.
So the minority, the racial minority in America, all of us, we look to this ideal of leadership as being a white male.
Whether it's a presidential leadership, a corporate leadership, a political leadership.
Whatever it is, we look to that.
And I think that it affirms that we still have this notion.
Claudia, good one.
Mined rock from which part of five-cent coins are made.
Mined rock - Nickel Ore.

So when you have the white male as the center, as the leader in every kind of context, then what happens is there is a development of a low self-esteem collectively in everybody who is under that in that hierarchy.
And what happens is, if you're under that, guess what, you attack everything that looks like you because in actuality you're expressing your own self-hatred.
So you hear that when you talk about minorities in the workplace.
They have the crab - we have the crab-in-the-barrel mentality sometimes when we see another minority elevated.
The same thing happens with women.
You hear the word catty in this study of people - women describing other women as catty 347 times.
That's amazing.
I've heard it a lot when we talk of - when I talk to other women who talk about this whole notion of following another woman leader.
I think that it's also interesting to point out, though, with hope in the future that younger workers, 18 to 29, had a greater preference for the female leaders.
So I think young people in each generation think differently, but it's a painstaking process of slow growth for a future that will allow us to look at women equally in a workplace.

So John, when you think about the public policy implications of this, does this really going to put the breaks on any kind of real gender equality in leadership, not just men putting the breaks on, not just men building the glass ceiling, but women building a glass ceiling?
Yeah.
It's there a little bit, and I think that all signs are that it's quite possible to surmount these things partly through this kind of awareness raising, kind of like black issues.
We're talking about these obstacles, these internalized stereotypes.
And they're there.

I've known many young women who have gone out into the world quite impatient with what they regard as an antiquated, feminist rhetoric, having never experienced anything they would consider sexism, and finding that, yes, there definitely is something there.
Now their attitude towards that is to stiffen to their backs and to work against it, not to become professional victims.
But nevertheless, we need to know that it's there.
I think, for example, that 97 percent of the visceral hatred that Hillary Clinton evinces from a certain crowd is because she is a woman.
A man, the exact same person but a man would just be seen as strong, she is seen as a b - - - h, I think, because of that.
They're things to think about; we're in a transitional stage.
Well, speaking of slurs against people, DJs seemed to be going after Barack Obama.
Sometimes these radio-shock jocks will cross the line…
This one's (unintelligible).
Yeah.
Well, look.
That's why we got to bring it up.
A Texas DJ called the presidential hopeful a clean darky.
He explained that it was part of an on-air conversation about Joe Biden's comments on the cleanliness of the senator…
He was making fun of Biden.
Yeah.
That's what he says.
That's what I thought.
It was in quotation marks.
I think we have to read that one in context.
He was on our side.
